Google Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A comics describing some design choices made when creating Chrome.

X.T: Tabbed Browsing in Google Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thinking about the way Chrome handles tabs.

X.T: Web Developers: Keeping Up With Google Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Web developers should use the beta channel to test the compatibility of their code with future Chrome releases.

X.T: Software Updates: Courgette

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of courgette, the compression mechanism used by Chrome to dramatically reduce the size of the updates.

X.T: GDD Moscow 2009. Расширения для Chrome (101) (ENG)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to writing Chrome extensions.

X.T: Google Chrome OS Demo

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Google Chrome for the holidays: Mac, Linux and extensions in beta

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The beta releases of Chrome for Mac and Linux and of the extensions.

X.T: Extensions in Incognito

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The user can now indicate which extensions are allowed in incognito mode.

X.T: Making Chrome more accessible with extensions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is releasing code to help writing accessibility extensions.

X.T: Release Early, Release Often

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome is going, from a 3 months, to a six weeks release cycle.

X.T: Do You Know How Slow Your Web Page Is?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome, IE, and Firefox are implementing the Web Timing draft specification.

X.T: WebP, a new image format for the Web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google creates a new image format… but the blog comments are quite clear: what is the need for this?

X.T: PDF goodness in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Native PDF support in Chrome.

X.T: Chrome is Ready for Business

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome now supports some administration features.

X.T: HTML Video Codec Support in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google gives some news about WebM and announces that, in Chrome, the <video> tag will not support H.264.

X.T: More about the Chrome HTML Video Codec Change

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google further explains its previous announcement.

X.T: Amping Up Chrome’s Background Feature

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome now supports background pages for applications without any visible window.

X.T: WebP in Chrome, Picasa, Gmail With a Slew of New Features and Improvements

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is still improving its own image format (fancy upsampling, segmented adaptation…) and is claiming to gain market acceptance.

X.T: New developer tools experimental APIs for Chrome extensions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An API extending developer tools.

X.T: Speed and Security

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A page can be prefetched while the user types its URL. Downloaded executable files are analyzed to check if they are known to be malicious.

X.T: Bringing Chromebooks to every classroom

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Marketting bullshit: Chromebook is a success in US schools.

X.T: Enhancing The Developer and End-User Experience on ChromeVox

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The intern in charge of cleaning up ChromeVox code gives some (very well-known) advice on having clean code. Then, the intern who performed ChromeVox integration in several Google products describes the API he created. At last, yet another intern describes the intelligent focus management.

X.T: Lossless and Transparency Modes in WebP

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: 10 Chrome tricks to improve your browsing experience
X.ST: No hacks, no registry tweaks, no add-ons: Just an arsenal of built-in tricks to make Chrome do your bidding.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: How to use 'Pin Tab' to organize your work in Google Chrome
X.ST: Google Chrome's "Pin Tab" feature is an often-overlooked option that can help power users organize their work in the browser and manage tab creep.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Disabling showModalDialog

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome is dropping support of showModalDialog.

X.T: New JavaScript techniques for rapid page loads

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Parallel parsing of the JavaScript and caching the compiled code.

X.T: Updates to Chrome platform support

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google stops supporting Chrome on Vista and XP.

X.T: Scroll anchoring for web developers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Avoiding page jumps while offscreen content is loaded.

X.T: Upcoming regular expression features

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JavaScript continues to catch up on regular expression capabilities compared to other languages.

X.T: Run multiple versions of Chrome side-by-side

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome, Chrome Beta, and Chrome Dev can now be installed side by side.

X.T: Introducing visualViewport

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: New in Chrome 61

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JavaScript modules, Web Share API, and WebUSB API.

X.T: Picture-in-Picture (PiP)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A proposal for a new API for creating a floating video window over other windows.

X.T: Introducing the Web Share API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An API to trigger the native Android share dialog.

X.T: Sensors For The Web!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A new API (Generic Sensor API) is added to access the accelerometer and gyroscope data.

X.T: Chrome 62 Beta: Network Quality Estimator API, OpenType variable fonts, and media capture from DOM elements

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Getting Started with Headless Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: New in Chrome 62

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Same content as for the 62 beta version.

X.T: Using Trusted Web Activities

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another way to integrate native and web applications.

X.T: Expanding user protections on the web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome includes some new mechanisms to detect and block unwanted navigation to a new page.

X.T: Reducing Chrome crashes caused by third-party software

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome will block most code injections performed on it.

X.T: New in Chrome 63

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Dynamic module imports, async iterators and generators, defining over-scroll behaviour, change in the dialogs for permission requests.

X.T: Enter Audio Worklet

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short description of AudioWorkletProcessor and AudioWorkletNode.

X.T: Preloading modules

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 64 adds the <link rel="modulepreload"> syntax for preloading modules.

X.T: Disabling hardware noise suppression

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google wants us to test the impact of hardware noise suppression on the sound quality of WebRTC.

X.T: The Device Memory API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the Device Memory API and several ways to use it.

X.T: Further protecting users from deceptive or confusing inline installation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is using machine learning to detect deceptive extension installations.

X.T: CSS Paint API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short description of the CSS Paint API.

X.T: The browser for a web worth protecting

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome will block adds not respecting the Better Ads Standards.

X.T: Under the hood: How Chrome's ad filtering works

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some informations on how ads will be blocked and how site owners can handle this.

X.T: macOS native echo cancellation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google experiments with using MacOS echo cancellation and wants people to test it for them.

X.T: New in Chrome 65

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The CSS Paint API, the Server Timing API, and the display: contents CSS property.

X.T: Credential Management API Feature Detection Check-up

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The way to perform feature detection for the Credential Management API must be updated to handle the PublicKeyCredential added by WebAuthn.

X.T: Unblocking Clipboard Access

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The text methods of the Asynchronous Clipboard API are now supported by Chrome.

X.T: Protecting users from extension cryptojacking

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cryptocurrency mining extensions will be removed from Chrome Web Store.

X.T: Working with the new CSS Typed Object Model

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 66 supports the CSS Typed Object Model, an object-oriented API to manipulate the CSS.

X.T: Present web pages to secondary attached displays

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 66 supports the Presentation API so an application can drive a secondary display.

X.T: New in Chrome 66

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The CSS Typed Model Object, the Asynchronous Clipboard API, and streamlined rendering of images in canvases.

X.T: BigInt: arbitrary-precision integers in JavaScript

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Chrome 67 Beta: WebXR Origin Trial, and Generic Sensors

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Generic Sensor API is now supported and a trial is started for WebXR Device API.

X.T: Improving Autoplay in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google still tries to get an adequate algorithm for accepting or ignoring autoplay.

X.T: Desktop Progressive Web Apps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The fact that PWAs are now supported on ChromeOS and some advice on designing a PWA so it is properly displayed on a desktop.

X.T: First Input Delay

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google proposes a new metric, First Input Delay: its definition, the difference with Time To Interactive and how to collect it.

X.T: Welcome to the immersive web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short introduction to the WebXR Device API.

X.T: New in Chrome 67

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Desktop PWAs, Generic Sensor API, BigIntand WebAuthn.

X.T: Changes to Add to Home Screen Behavior

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all, yet another modification to Add to Home Screen and this will change again in the future.

X.T: Fresher service workers, by default

ARTICLE.COMMENT: By default, the HTTP cache will be bypassed when fetching the service worker script.

X.T: Chrome 68 Beta: add to home screen, payment handler, page lifecycle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Changed add to home screen behaviour, Payment Handler API, some redirections now require a user gesture, Page Lifecycle API, fetching a service worker script bypasses the cache…

X.T: Bring your payment method to the web with the Payment Handler API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the Payment Handler API.

X.T: Improving extension transparency for users

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Extension inline installation will be removed in a few months.

X.T: Augmented reality for the web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the WebXR Hit Test API.

X.T: Chacmool: Augmented reality in Chrome Canary

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Presentation of an AR demo and some advice for building AR applications.

X.T: More native echo cancellation!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same than 3 months ago with MacOS: Google asks people to test Windows native noise cancellation, explaining that they already know it does work properly.

X.T: Experimenting with First Input Delay in the Chrome UX Report

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome UX now report the First Input Delay (the duration between the user intercation and the Browser responding to it).

X.T: Introduction to Feature Policy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Feature Policy: Feature-Policy HTTP header, iframe's allow attribute, and JavaScript API.

X.T: Page Lifecycle API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the Page Lifecycle API and how to properly use it.

X.T: New in Chrome 68

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some changes in Add to Home and in the Payment Handler API, addition of the ScreenPage Lifecycle API, redirecting from an iframe requires a user gesture, HTTP cache is bypassed when upgrading a service worker

X.T: Bringing Google Pay to PaymentRequest

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The basic-card payment method is replaced by the Google Pay API.

X.T: Introducing NoState Prefetch

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An explanation of how the NoState Prefetch works.

X.T: Chrome 69 Beta: CSS tricks, and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 69 Beta contains many changes: CSS new features, OffscreenCanvas, new or improved APIs, mid-ligature text selection…

X.T: ReportingObserver: know your code health

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The ReportingObserver API can be used to programmatically detect the deprecation and intervention reports generated by Chrome.

X.T: Well-Controlled Scrolling with CSS Scroll Snap

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the new version of CSS Scroll Snap and its current implementation status in Chrome.

X.T: Audio/Video Updates in Chrome 69

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Support of AV1 codec, querying the supported EME encryption schemes, the new HDCP Policy Check API…

X.T: OffscreenCanvas — Speed up Your Canvas Operations with a Web Worker

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of OffscreenCanvas.

X.T: New in Chrome 69

ARTICLE.COMMENT: CSS Scroll Snap, managing display on screens with notches, and the Web Locks API.

X.T: The ‘Capable Web’: A 10 Year Retrospective

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A summary of the history of Chrome.

X.T: The Reporting API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A Report-To HTTP Header defines to which endpoint the errors of each type should be reported.

X.T: Asynchronous Access to HTTP Cookies

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice to not use cookies and a description of the Cookie Store API.

X.T: How we designed Chrome 10 years ago

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The four core principles: simplicity, speed, security, and stability.

X.T: Chrome 70 beta: shape detection, web authentication, and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Shape Detection API (Face Detection API, Barcode Detection API and Text Detection API) has been added and numerous small changes have been made.

X.T: Audio/Video Updates in Chrome 70

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Switching the codec and bytestream format, support of Opus in MP4, and protected content playback now allowed by default.

X.T: Product updates based on your feedback

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is making profile management even more unclear: when you sign into any Google website, you'll also be signed into Chrome with the same account.

X.T: Houdini's Animation Worklet

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another animation API: AnimationWorklet.

X.T: New in Chrome 70

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Desktop Progressive Web Apps now available on Windows, Public Key Credentials, and Web Worker names.

X.T: Tweaks to cache.addAll() and importScripts() coming in Chrome 71

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Two non upward compatible changes: importScripts() cannot be called asynchronously and cache.addAll() rejects duplicated URLs.

X.T: Watch video using Picture-in-Picture

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to the Picture-in-Picture Web API.

X.T: The Intl.RelativeTimeFormat API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Chrome 71 Beta: relative time formats and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Intl.RelativeTimeFormat API and numerous small changes.

X.T: Signed HTTP Exchanges

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An origin trial for Signed HTTP Exchange, a mechanism to publish a Web Package from a site other that its origin, is started.

X.T: Further protections from harmful ad experiences on the web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google creates a black list of sites with abusive ads, Chrome will remove all ads on these ones.

X.T: Notifying users of unclear subscription pages

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google wants to fight hidden billing, but I do not understand how Chrome can automatically detect that.

X.T: Web Audio, Autoplay Policy and Games

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The rules for allowing autoplay have been slightly changed after having received some feedback from the Web developers.

X.T: New in Chrome 71

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Intl.RelativeTimeFormat(), specifying underline location for vertical text and speech synthesis now requires user activation.

X.T: Introducing Background Fetch

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the Background Fetch API.

X.T: Registering as a Share Target with the Web Share Target API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An explanation on how to use the Web Share Target API which is available in Chrome 71.

X.T: Badging for App Icons

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the simple Badging API and a call for comments.

X.T: Public and private class fields

ARTICLE.COMMENT: V8 starts to support public/private (possibly static) fields and private static methods.

X.T: I’m Awake! Stay Awake with the WakeLock API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the Wake Lock API (to prevent the device from going to sleep or from locking the screen) and a call for comments.

X.T: The Intl.ListFormat API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Intl.ListFormat has been added to format lists.

X.T: Chrome 72 Beta: Public class fields, user activation and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Public class fields, User Activation Query API, Intl.ListFormat()…

X.T: Check If Your Native App Is Installed With getInstalledRelatedApps

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the getInstalledRelatedApps API (to list related apps) and a call for comments

X.T: A Picture is Worth a Thousand Words, Faces, and Barcodes—The Shape Detection API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A call for comments on FaceDetector, BarcodeDetector, and TextDetector.

X.T: Making user activation consistent across APIs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 72 has new version of User Activation.

X.T: New in Chrome 72

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same content as in the beta.

X.T: RTCQuicTransport Coming to an Origin Trial Near You (Chrome 73)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google wants some feedback about RTCQuicTransport, an API for peer to peer communication using the QUIC protocol.

X.T: Introducing a Trusted Web Activity for Android

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trusted Web Activity allows to run a Chrome browser full screen in an Android application.

X.T: Using Trusted Web Activities

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed description on how to set up a TWA application.

X.T: Better match results with String.prototype.matchAll()

ARTICLE.COMMENT: String.prototype.matchAll() can be used to easily iterate on the matches of a regex.

X.T: Making wheel scrolling fast by default

ARTICLE.COMMENT: wheel and mousewheel listeners registered on root targets are now passive by default.

X.T: The model-viewer web component

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of <model-viewer>, a Web Component displaying 3D models.

X.T: Audio/Video Updates in Chrome 73

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Support of hardware media keys, automated switch to Picture-in-Picture mode, support of Skip Ad action in Picture-in-Picture…

X.T: Chrome 73 Beta: Constructable stylesheets, a new RegExp function, and passive mouse events

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Constructable stylesheets, String.prototype.matchAll(), passive mousewheel listeners, and many other changes.

X.T: Constructable Stylesheets: seamless reusable styles

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is now possible to construct a Style Sheet using replace() or replaceSync(), and attach it to Shadow Roots and Documents using the adoptedStyleSheets property.

X.T: Get Ready for Priority Hints

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A detailed description of Priority Hints, a Chrome 73 feature enabling the developer to tune resource loading priorities.

X.T: Trusted Types help prevent Cross-Site Scripting

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome experiments with a mechanism to sanitize strings before injecting them in the DOM.

X.T: Trust is Good, Observation is Better—Intersection Observer v2

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The new version of IntersectionObserver supports testing the visibility of a DOM element. This is aimed at detecting clickjacking used for generating ad clicks.

X.T: Exploring a back/forward cache for Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Move Ya! Or maybe, don't, if the user prefers-reduced-motion!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The media query prefers-reduced-motion can be used to test if the use wants limited animations.

X.T: KV Storage: the Web's First Built-in Module

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of build-in modules, of the KV storage, an asynchronous key/value storage, and how to be compatible with old browsers .

X.T: New in Chrome 73

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Progressive Web Apps on all desktop platforms, signed HTTP exchanges, and constructable style sheets.

X.T: Chrome Lite Pages - For a faster, leaner loading experience

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the Data Saver feature, but the technical details on how it works are not clear.

X.T: Chrome 74 beta: reducing unwanted motion, private class fields, and feature policy API

ARTICLE.COMMENT: CSS prefers-reduced-motion media query, private class fields, a new API for feature policy…

X.T: Data Saver is now Lite mode

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The name of the feature is changed.

X.T: New in Chrome 74

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Private class fields, prefers-reduced-motion, CSS transition events, additions to the feature policy API.

X.T: Share files with Web Share

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Web Share API now supports sharing files.

X.T: Low-latency rendering with the desynchronized hint

ARTICLE.COMMENT: canvas.getContext() nows supports the desynchronized hint to skip as much compositing as possible.

X.T: Chrome 75 Beta: low latency canvas contexts, sharing files, and numeric separators

ARTICLE.COMMENT: desynchronized hint for canvas.getContext(), files are supported by the Web Share API, numeric literals allow underscores…

X.T: Paint Holding - reducing the flash of white on same-origin navigations

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome will not diplay anymore a white screen when loading a new page if this one is displayed fast enough.

X.T: Augmented reality with model-viewer

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The <model-viewer> Web Component now supports displaying the source image on top of the camera feed.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of recent and future improvements.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Still some tweaking of the "Add to Home screen" feature.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same features as for the beta release.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the problems fixed by the new layout engine.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another evolution of the PWA installation.

X.T: Updating WebAPKs More Frequently

ARTICLE.COMMENT: PWA updates are now checked every day instead of every three days.

X.T: Chrome 76 Beta: dark mode, payments, new PWA features and more

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The new prefers-color-scheme media query, changes of the Payments API, improvement of the PWA installation, controlling the Add to Home Screen mini-infobar, more frequent updates of PWAs…

X.T: New Chrome Protections from Deception

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Detection of confusing URLs and an extension to report suspicious sites.

X.T: Easier Payments with Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome will now autofill payment information in forms even without Chrome sync being disabled.

X.T: Image Support for the Async Clipboard API

X.T: Web Components update: more time to upgrade to v1 APIs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Web Components v0 will be removed, this article explains how to disable them in order to test that an application works without them and how to install the polyfills.

X.T: Protecting private browsing in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Sites will not be able anymore to use the FileSystem API to detect that the user is in Incognito Mode.

X.T: Project Strobe: Updates to Our User Data Policy

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Accessing the least amount of data is now a requirement, more extensions are required to provide a privacy policy.

X.T: New in Chrome 76

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same features as for the beta release (but the payment API improvements have not been listed here).

X.T: Audio/Video Updates in Chrome 75

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Media Capabilities API can now be used to query encrypted media capabilities, video's playsInline attribute hints to display the display the video inline.

X.T: A Contact Picker for the Web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Contact Picker API is beginning its trial phase.

X.T: Chrome 77 Beta: New performance metrics, new form capabilities, capabilities in origin trials and more

X.T: Keeping spam off the Chrome Web Store

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome Web Store spam policy is updated.

X.T: Introducing Web Vitals: essential metrics for a healthy site

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google defined three metrics (Largest Contentful Paint, First Input Delay, and Cumulative Layout Shift) and include them in some tools and in a Chrome extension.

X.T: Protecting against resource-heavy ads in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Ads which are using too much CPU or network will be disabled.

X.T: New in Chrome 83

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trusted types, updated form controls, performance.measureMemory(), additions to the Native File System API, and Web vitals.

X.T: The Science Behind Web Vitals

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some research results are given to rationalize the Web vitals metrics, but this is quite different from the metrics Google proposed a few years ago…

X.T: Celebrating 10 years of WebM and WebRTC

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Chrome 84 Beta: Web OTP, Web Animations, New Origin Trials and More

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Web OTP API, a new implementation of the Web Animations API, several new origin trials (Cookie Store API, Idle Detection, Origin Isolation, WebAssembly SIMD, Content Indexing API, and promises in the Wake Lock API)…

X.T: Protecting Chrome users from abusive notifications

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Notifications will be disabled on site abusing them.

X.T: Resuming SameSite Cookie Changes in July

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Improving Chromium's browser compatibility in 2020

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome team will work on improving compatibility for Flexbox, scrolling, form controls, and CSS Grid.

X.T: Changes to quality criteria for PWAs using Trusted Web Activity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A TWA crash will now be reported as a native application crash.

X.T: New in Chrome 84

ARTICLE.COMMENT: App icon shortcuts, Web Animations API improvements, Content Indexing API to indicate the avaibility of some offline data, and Wake lock API.

X.T: Chrome 85: Upload Streaming, Human Interface Devices, Custom Properties with Inheritance and More

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Fetch upload streaming to be able to start uploading before having all the data, the WebHID API enables implementing device-specific logic, navigator.getInstalledRelatedApps() is now avalilable on Windows, CSS @property…

X.T: Using Chrome to generate more accessible PDFs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google is experimenting with generating tagged PDFs.

X.T: Changes to the Chrome App Support Timeline

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Helping people spot the spoofs: a URL experiment

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all: Google experiments displaying only the domain.

X.T: ChromeOS.dev — A blueprint to build world-class apps and games for Chrome OS

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
The launch of ChromeOS.devhttps://chromeos.dev/
enHTML and some new ChromeOS features: customizable terminal, Android Emulator, improved Project Wizard in Android Studio…

X.T: Highlighting great user experiences on the mobile web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 85 will indicate URLs which have good Core Web Vitals metrics.

X.T: Organize your tabs and stay productive in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tab improvements (speed, collapsing tab groups, improved tablet mode, switching to a tab from the search autocompletion, tab preview), PDF saving, and easier URL sharing.

X.T: Chrome just got faster with Profile Guided Optimization

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some very little information about two performance improvements: Profile Guided Optimization and throttling background tabs.

X.T: New in Chrome 85

ARTICLE.COMMENT: content-visibility: auto to delay the rendering of an element, CSS custom properties can be defined in CSS, getInstalledRelatedApps() to test if an application is already installed, App Icon Shortcuts on Windows…

X.T: Giving users and developers more control over focus

ARTICLE.COMMENT: :focus always displays the style when the widget has has the focus, :focus-visible only displays the style if the situation matches the focus indicator heuristic. Quick Focus Highlight has been added.

X.T: Chrome 86: Improved Focus Highlighting, WebHID, and More

ARTICLE.COMMENT: :focus-visible; Quick Focus Highlight; origin trials of WebHID (human interface devices) API, multi-screen information API, battery-savings Meta Tag, Secure Payment Confirmation, and COOP reporting API; Native File System API is finalized.

X.T: Changing the Chrome on iOS User Agent for Request Desktop Site

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The User-Agent string sent when the page is in desktop mode is now different from the Safari one.

X.T: Progress on Privacy Sandbox and building a more private web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The statuses of the privacy improvements.

X.T: New in Chrome 86

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Native File System API is finalized, WebHID API and Multi-Screen Window Placement API are in origin trial, and :focus-visible.

X.T: Chrome is deploying HTTP/3 and IETF QUIC

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Chrome 87 Beta: WebAuthn in DevTools, Pan/Tilt/Zoom, Flow Relative Shorthands and More

ARTICLE.COMMENT: WebAuthn tab, camera pan/tilt/zoom control, CSS shorthands for flow-relative properties, Cookie Store API is out of trial…

X.T: Reducing abusive notification content

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google will will block notification permission requests for sites sending abusive notification content.

X.T: New in Chrome 87

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Camera pan/tilt/zoom, range requests and service workers, and the Local Font Access API.

X.T: Tab throttling and more performance improvements in Chrome M87

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Timers wake-ups of background tabs are throttled and a cache has been added for backward/foward history navigation.

X.T: A faster Chrome, for everything you need to get done

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Performance improvements, searching for tabs in any window, typing actions in the omnibox, and new tabs will propose some pages visited before.

X.T: Transparent privacy practices for Chrome Extensions

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The list of collected data will be easier to read by end users and the user data privacy policy contains new limitations.

X.T: Chrome 88: Digital Goods, Lighting Estimation in Augmented Reality, and More

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Digital Goods API, AR Lighting Estimation in WebXR…

X.T: Abandonment

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some musing on how to define a metric for abandonment.

X.T: Seamless payments and password management in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Saved passwords and payment methods will be retrievable wthout sync being turned on.

X.T: Manifest V3 now available on M88 Beta

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Removal of remotely hosted code, service workers replace background pages, adding APIs such as declarativeNetRequest that do not give access to private data, and the planning for the migration to Manifest V3.

X.T: Making Chrome extensions more private and secure

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It will now be possible to restrict an extension to some sites.

X.T: Chrome Dev Summit 2020: Building an open web for our users and developers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of more or less recent announcements.

X.T: New in Chrome 88

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Manifest v3, aspect-ratio CSS property, throttling of chained JS timers, and Play Billing is usable in a Trusted Web Activity.

X.T: Limiting Private API availability in Chromium

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Starting March 15, private Chrome APIs will be usable only in Chrome.

X.T: Better content sharing with Custom Tabs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome will automatically add a share button on applications using Custom Tabs.

X.T: Chrome 89 Beta: Advanced Hardware Interactions, Web Sharing on Desktop, and More

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some features are enabled on some OSes (WebHID API, Web NFC, Web Serial API, Web Sharing), support of AVIF images, COOP reporting API…

X.T: Heads Up: Restriction on SharedArrayBuffers are coming in M91

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some APIs will be accessible only if the page uses cross-origin isolation.

X.T: Create a space for yourself in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very short description of profile management.

X.T: Speeding up Chrome's release cycle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Starting with Chrome 94, there will be a release every 4 weeks.

X.T: Chrome 90 Beta: AV1 Encoder for WebRTC, New Origin Trials, and More

ARTICLE.COMMENT: AV1 Encoder, V8 upgraded to 9.0, aspect-ratio property is now interpolable, CSS pseudo classes for the states of custom elements…

X.T: Chrome can now caption audio and video

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome is now able to (locally) generate captions.

X.T: Privacy, sustainability and the importance of “and”

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google proposes Federated Learning of Cohorts (FLoC) to be able to continue to sell adds while respecting a little more privacy.

X.T: Experiment with AR and VR made for the web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some demos using WebXR.

X.T: A more helpful Chrome, throughout your workday

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An advertisement for the latest Chrome features.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short summary of the security analysis for extensions.

X.T: Security in Depth: New Security Features

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some new security features have been integrated in Chrome 4: the Strict-Transport-Security header, the postMessage API, the Origin header, the X-Frame-Options header, and protection against reflective XSS.

X.T: Security in Depth: HTML5’s @sandbox

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome now supports iframe's sandbox attribute.

X.T: Protecting users from malicious downloads

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome checks downloaded files against the Safe Browsing blacklist.

X.T: New Chromium security features, June 2011

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of security improvements in Chrome 11, 12 and 13: strong random numbers, HSTS, blocked HTTP basic auth for sub-resource loads…

X.T: Chromebook security: browsing more securely

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of some security features of Chromebooks: a read-only firmware check the signature of the BIOS and the OS, auto-updates (who is not doing this?), reinstall the OS from an USB storage (same comment)…

X.T: More secure extensions, by default

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 18 will have Content Security Policy enabled by default.

X.T: Fuzzing for Security

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of ClusterFuzz, an infrastructure running 50.000.000 tests per day on the latest stable build and analyzing the crashes.

X.T: A Tale of Two Pwnies (Part 1)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An impressive use of several Chrome bugs to get full privileges on the user's machine (and win 60000$).

X.T: A Tale Of Two Pwnies (Part 2)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A similar story.

X.T: Gradually Sunsetting SHA-1

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Certificates using SHA-1 and expiring after 2017-01-01 will be considered insecure.

X.T: Say “yes” to HTTPS: Chrome secures the web, one site at a time

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome's security messages result into more and more sites using HTTPS.

X.T: Meltdown/Spectre

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on how site owners can limit Meltdown/Spectre attacks and what the Chrome team is doing on its side.

X.T: A secure web is here to stay

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome 68 will report HTTP sites as insecure.

X.T: Enabling Strong Authentication with WebAuthn

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short presentation of WebAuthn.

X.T: Evolving Chrome's security indicators

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Once again, the same message about reporting HTTP sites as insecure, but the target is now Chrome 70.

X.T: Trustworthy Chrome Extensions, by default

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some security improvements for extensions: host permissions, code obfuscation is now disallowed, two steps verification for store developers, manifest V3.

X.T: Improving privacy and security on the web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Google claims that it will give users more control on cross site cookies and add protection against fingerprinting.

X.T: Recent Site Isolation improvements

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about the Site Isolation on Android and the improvements on desktop.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Debunking some false claims about Google's decision to promote DNS-over-HTTPS.

X.T: Better password protections in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Report of a password that was compromised in a data breach, real-time phishing protection, predictive phishing protection, and a new visual representation of the profile.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Insecure downloads from an HTTPS page will gradually be blocked.

X.T: New malware protections for Advanced Protection users

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: Keep tabs on your tabs in Google Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tab groups have been added.

X.T: More intuitive privacy and security controls in Chrome

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Safety check, third-party cookies are blocked by default in incognito mode, Enhanced Safe Browsing, extension puldown, Secure DNS.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The current status of the switch to DNS-over-HTTPS.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Biometrics will be usable to confirm the autofilling of credit card information, a new diaog to autofill login and password fields.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Forms not submitted with HTTPS will not be autofilled and will need to be confirmed with a warning message.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Secure DNS in arriving for Chrome on Android.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Chrome DevTools now supports the DWARF debugging format, this allows stepping over code, setting breakpoints, and resolving stack traces.

X.T: New developer dashboard and registration flow for Chrome Web Store

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The new developper dashboard is now the default one, fees must now be paid even if the developper published nothing.

X.T: Simulating color vision deficiencies in the Blink Renderer

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How the simulator of color vision deficiencies has been implemented.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the improvements and remaining limitations for debugging C/C++ applications.

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 65)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Edits of CSS and JavaScript can be saved locally, some tools to inspect accessibility, some new Lighthouse checks, improved code stepping.

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 66)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Showing the real initiator of a network request rather that the API wrapping the call, the same when setting breakpoints, minified resources are prettified, preview of the HTML payload of a request, improved local overrides, and auto-adjust zoom in Device Mode.

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 67)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Search across all network headers and responses, search UI improvements, copy as fetch, audit improvements, stop current JavaScript call, the Performance tabs now contains User Timing measures…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 68)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Improved console (expression result preview, argument tooltip, autocomplete on function results, ES2017), Lighthouse 3.0, BigInt and Add property path to watch.

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 70)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Continuous display of the value of a pinned expression, highlight of the DOM element which is the result of an eager evaluation, better 3G emulation…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 71)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Hovering over a Live Expression highlights the DOM node, initiator and priority information is stored in HAR files, breakpoints for Picture-in-Picture events…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 72)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Performance metrics in the timeline, text nodes are highlighted in the viewport, generating a JavaScript expression which is the path of a shadow node, Lighthouse upgraded to 3.2.

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 73)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Logpoint (quick way to log the value of an expression in the console), the node inspection tooltip nows contains style properties, export of code coverage data, keyboard navigation of the console, contrast guidelines in the Color Picker, saving custom geolocation overrides…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 74)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Highlight of the nodes impacted by a CSS property, Lighthouse upgraded to v4, display of WebSocket binary messages, filtering service workers in the Network panel…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 75)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A default value is now set when autocompleting a CSS property, the Clear Site Data command, all IndexedDB databases can now be displayed, the Breakpoints pane now supports several breakpoints on the same line of code…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 76)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Autocomplete with CSS values, WebSocket messages in HAR exports, real time evolution of the memory usage, Puppeteer for Firefox and some UI improvements.

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 77)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Copy the style of an element in the clipboard, visualization of layout shifts, upgrade to Lighthouse 5.1, recording of Push Messages and Notifications…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 78)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Audits panel can be used in combination with other DevTools features, debugging Payment Handlers, improved Lighthouse, and reporting DevTools issues.

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 79)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Debugging blocked cookies, display of a cookie value, emulation of prefers-color-scheme and prefers-reduced-motion preferences, improved code coverage display, call stack when a given request was performed…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 80)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: let and class can be used in the console, the Request Initiator Chain can be displayed, per-function or per-block coverage…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 81)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Improved tools for cookies, Moto G4 added in device mode, hover display of CSS properties now displays unescaped strings…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 83)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Emulation of vision deficiencies, debugging of COOP and COEP, maskable icon support…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 84)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The new Issues tab, accessibility information in the Inspect Mode tooltip, display of the Total Blocking Time, analysis of layout shifts…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 85)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Editing styles created with the CSSOM API, Lighthouse 6, better support of the new JavaScript features, Performance panel improvements…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 86)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: New Media panel, screenshots can be done from the context menu, emulation of missing local fonts, emulation of idle users, Lighthouse 6.2…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 87)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: CSS Grid debugging, WebAuthn tab, positioning any tool at the top or the bottom, grouping CSS properties, Lighthouse 6.4, resource-type and url filters in the Network panel…

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 89)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Breakpoints in Trusted Type violations, improved screenshots, Trust Tokens tab, Lighthouse 7… and many other small improvements.

X.T: What's New In DevTools (Chrome 90)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Improved debugging of flexbox elements, the Core Web Vitals overlay, reporting of Trusted Web Activity issues, the Trust Tokens pane, deprecation of fn.displayName which is replaced by fn.name…
